Award.AwardTitle: TWC: Small: Collaborative: Computation and Access Control on Big Multiuser Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is developing new foundational cryptographic techniques for outsourcing data and computations on it, which fully preserve data privacy. The focus is on real-world settings involving multiple users where privacy with respect to all other users is required, as well as privacy from the service provider. The project will aim to minimize the interaction between users in the system, making the computational complexity for each client independent of the total number of users. The investigators are developing protocols that allow many users to outsource their data to a cloud provider and later access it obliviously with respect to both the provider and other users while achieving as closely as possible the above efficiency requirements. This enables not only access but also computation over the outsourced data using a more efficient computational model called random access machines.

These techniques aim to minimize the work performed by the users as well as the communication between users and the service provider. The project develops cryptographic techniques that protect data privacy while enabling its use in cloud computing. Resolving these issues is of increasing importance due to the explosion of data produced by people and machines. The investigators are committed to the dissemination of research results and education of students in this area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Data is one of the most valuable resources nowadays. However, using data collected from various sources poses serious privacy risks for the subjects. Cryptographic techniques propose uniquely positioned solutions for such challenges that allows to use private data in a controlled manner that both achieves the desired utility while preserving the maximum privacy guarantees for the underlying data. The work developed under this grant has enhanced our capabilities enabled by such cryptographic primitives. It can be classified in two main directions: achieving new functionalities that were not known how to obtain before and bringing known approaches closer to practical uses developing optimized solutions and implementation. In the first category we have developed new tools based on obfuscation and multilinear maps including:


- New construction for order revealing encryption - the first implementable encryption system supporting greater-than comparisons on encrypted data that provides the ``best-possible'' semantic security, Eurocrypt 2015


- New Protocol for RAM computation outsourcing - the first schemes that allow a client to privately outsource arbitrary program executions to a remote server while ensuring that: (I) the client's work is small and essentially independent of the complexity of the computation being outsourced, and (II) the server's work is only proportional to the run-time of the computation on a random access machine (RAM), FOCS 2014


- An adaptively secure, efficiency-preserving, succinct and persistent garbling scheme for RAM programs that guarantees 1.The time to garble the memory is proportional to the plaintext memory. 2 The garbling time and size of the garbled program are proportional only to the size of the plaintext RAM program. 3.The runtime and space usage of each garbled machine are comparable to those of the plaintext machine. , TCC 2016


- Cryptanalysis on CLT multilinear maps - we extend the attacks from  the work of  CHLRS14 and apply them against both CLT13 encodings and a matrix variant of GGH13 encodings, even in settings where no low-level encodings of zero are available to the adversary, Crypto 2015


- Non-committing encryption with optimal rate - we developed the first construction of a constant-rate NCE. Our scheme has rate 1 + o(1), which is comparable to the efficiency of plain semantically secure encryption., Asiacrypt 2017


In the second research thrust aiming at efficiency constructions we have developed the following tools:


- Private Database Access Protocol using homomorphic encryption and ORAM - We examined the feasibility of the secure-computation-over-ORAM approach, focusing specifically on secure-computation protocols based on somewhat-homomorphic encryption (SWHE), ACNS 2015


- New construction for square root ORAM - we show how the classical square-root ORAM of Goldreich and Ostrovsky can be modified to achieve the best concrete access complexity for average size databases, IEEES&P 2016


- Privacy-enhanced routing protocol for information-centric networks - we describe the design, implementation, and evaluation of a security framework that ensures the integrity and confidentiality of published content, the associated descriptive metadata, and the interests of subscribers in information-centric networks, ACSAC 2015


- Secure computation framework for linear regression - we conducted a comprehensive evaluation and comparison of different techniques for securely performing linear regression, including a new Conjugate Gradient Descent (CGD) algorithm., PETS 2017


- Protocol for outsourced database Boolean queries - we constructed a new encrypted search scheme that reduces the leakage of Boolean queries while introducing limited overhead and preserving the sublinear efficiency properties for the search protocol from BlindSeer, CT-RSA 2017


The results of our work have moved the frontier of what we know is possible to achieve with cryptographic tools and what we know about efficiently implementing some of these tools in order to be used in practice. We have disseminated our work widely at conference and workshop venue as well as through a series of invited talks.
